title: Enterprise Network Design Principles
note: This lesson covers enterprise network design principles, including the 2-tier, 3-tier, and spine-leaf architectures. It also introduces modern concepts like SD-WAN and SD-Access for building intelligent and automated wide-area and campus networks. The context is the CCNP ENCOR exam blueprint.

title: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) Deep Dive
note: A deep dive into STP and its variants (RSTP, MSTP). This lesson covers the election of the root bridge, port roles (root, designated, alternate), and how to manipulate STP behavior using priority values and port costs to build a resilient, loop-free Layer 2 topology.

title: Advanced VLANs and Trunking
note: This section moves beyond basic VLANs to cover advanced topics like VLAN Trunking Protocol (VTP) for centralized VLAN management and Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP) for negotiating trunk links. The security implications and best practices for each are discussed.

title: Configuring EtherChannel
note: This lesson provides a detailed guide to configuring link aggregation with EtherChannel. It covers both the Cisco-proprietary PAgP and the industry-standard LACP negotiation protocols, and explains the different load-balancing algorithms that can be used.

title: First Hop Redundancy Protocols (FHRP)
note: This section covers protocols for providing default gateway redundancy. It details the configuration and operation of HSRP (Hot Standby Router Protocol), VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol), and GLBP (Gateway Load Balancing Protocol).

title: Advanced EIGRP: Path Calculation
note: A deep dive into the EIGRP routing protocol. This lesson focuses on the DUAL (Diffusing Update Algorithm) finite state machine and how EIGRP calculates its composite metric using bandwidth and delay. The concepts of Feasible Distance and Reported Distance are explained.

title: Advanced EIGRP: Optimization
note: This lesson covers techniques for optimizing EIGRP. It includes manual route summarization to reduce the size of routing tables, configuring unequal-cost load balancing with the 'variance' command, and managing EIGRP neighbor relationships.

title: Advanced OSPF: LSA Types and Areas
note: This section provides a deep dive into OSPF. It details the different OSPF LSA (Link-State Advertisement) types and explains the concept of a multi-area OSPF design, including backbone, standard, stub, and NSSA areas.

title: Advanced OSPF: Configuration and Verification
note: This lesson covers the practical implementation of multi-area OSPF. It demonstrates how to configure OSPF areas, summarization, and other advanced features. It also covers the `show` commands used to verify OSPF neighbor states, the database, and the routing table.

title: Route Redistribution
note: This lesson explains how to configure route redistribution, the process of exchanging routing information between different routing protocols (e.g., between EIGRP and OSPF). It covers the challenges of redistribution, such as routing loops and metric manipulation.

title: Controlling Redistribution with Route Maps
note: This section introduces route maps as a powerful tool for controlling routing policy. It demonstrates how to use route maps with `match` and `set` commands to filter which routes are redistributed and to modify their metrics.

title: Introduction to BGP
note: This lesson introduces BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) as the routing protocol of the internet. It explains the difference between Internal BGP (iBGP) and External BGP (eBGP) and covers the fundamental concepts of Autonomous Systems (AS) and path attributes.

title: BGP Path Selection
note: This section details the BGP best-path selection algorithm. It covers the sequence of path attributes that BGP uses to select the best route to a destination, including Weight, Local Preference, AS_PATH, and MED (Multi-Exit Discriminator).

title: Configuring eBGP and iBGP
note: This lesson provides a practical guide to configuring BGP. It demonstrates how to establish eBGP peerings between different Autonomous Systems and iBGP peerings within the same AS. Verification commands for checking neighbor status and received routes are covered.

title: Virtualization with VRF-Lite
note: This lesson introduces VRF (Virtual Routing and Forwarding) as a technology to create multiple virtual routers within a single physical router. It demonstrates how to configure VRF-Lite to segment routing tables and create isolated network paths.

title: GRE Tunneling
note: This section covers Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE), a simple tunneling protocol for encapsulating a wide variety of network layer protocols inside virtual point-to-point links over an IP network.

title: Introduction to MPLS
note: This lesson provides an overview of MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching). It explains how MPLS works by adding labels to packets and making forwarding decisions based on those labels, creating a high-speed and flexible core network.

title: Dynamic Multipoint VPN (DMVPN)
note: This section introduces DMVPN as a scalable solution for building VPNs. It explains the components of DMVPN: mGRE (multipoint GRE) tunnels, NHRP (Next Hop Resolution Protocol), and IPsec for encryption, allowing for dynamic spoke-to-spoke communication.

title: Infrastructure Security: AAA
note: This lesson covers how to secure device management access using the AAA framework. It demonstrates how to configure local authentication and how to use RADIUS or TACACS+ for centralized authentication with a server.

title: Infrastructure Security: CoPP
note: This section introduces Control Plane Policing (CoPP), a mechanism to protect the router's CPU from denial-of-service attacks by rate-limiting traffic destined for the control plane.

title: Infrastructure Services: Advanced NAT
note: This lesson covers more advanced Network Address Translation scenarios, including policy-based NAT and configuring NAT for different VRFs, which is essential in complex enterprise networks.

title: Network Assurance: Syslog and SNMP
note: This section covers key network monitoring protocols. It explains how to configure devices to send log messages to a central Syslog server and how to use SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) to poll devices for performance data and receive traps for important events.

title: Network Assurance: NetFlow
note: This lesson introduces NetFlow as a technology for collecting and analyzing IP traffic information. It explains how NetFlow data can be used for network monitoring, security analysis, and traffic profiling.

title: Network Assurance: SPAN/RSPAN
note: This section covers Switched Port Analyzer (SPAN) and Remote SPAN (RSPAN) as tools for traffic analysis. It demonstrates how to configure a switch to mirror traffic from source ports or VLANs to a destination port connected to a network analyzer.

title: Advanced Wireless LANs
note: This lesson expands on wireless topics, covering advanced concepts such as RF design principles, roaming between access points, and the configuration of multiple SSIDs on a Wireless LAN Controller (WLC).

title: Wireless Security
note: This section provides a deep dive into securing wireless networks. It covers the configuration of WPA2 and WPA3 security protocols, and demonstrates how to set up Enterprise authentication using 802.1X and a RADIUS server.

title: Introduction to Network Automation
note: This section introduces the modern approach to network management through automation. It explains the benefits of programmability and covers the foundational concepts of using scripts and APIs to configure and monitor network devices.

title: Working with Data Formats: JSON and YANG
note: This lesson covers the data formats used in network automation. It explains the structure of JSON and introduces YANG as a data modeling language for network device configuration. The relationship between these formats is discussed.

title: REST APIs and NETCONF/RESTCONF
note: This section introduces the primary protocols for interacting with network devices programmatically. It covers the principles of REST APIs and introduces NETCONF and RESTCONF as standardized protocols for network configuration and management.

title: Configuration Management Tools
note: This lesson provides an overview of popular configuration management tools like Ansible, Puppet, and Chef, explaining how they can be used to automate the deployment and management of network infrastructure in a declarative, scalable way.
